questions.text: All of the following structures pass through the marked arrow notch except-
questions.solution:
The marked arrow notch is the lesser sciatic notch.

The structures passing through the lesser sciatic notch are as follow: (Mnemonics: PINTO)

  • Pudendal nerve
  • Internal pudendal vessels
  • Nerve to obturator internus
  • Tendon of Obturator internus

Educational objective: Common structures in greater and lesser sciatic notch: Pudendal nerve, Internal pudendal vessels

choices.text: It is first tarsal bone to ossify
It is only tarsal bone that does not have muscle attachment
It is longest and strongest tarsal bone
It have shelf life projection of bone called sustentaculum tali

questions.text: All of the statements are true for marked bone in the image except
questions.solution:
The marked bone is calcaneum.

  • The calcaneus is the largest tarsal bone.
  • It forms the prominence of the heel.
  • It is Cuboidal in shape and has six surfaces.
  • The medial surface is concave from above downwards . The concavity is accentuated by the presence of shelf like projection of bone called the sustentaculum tali.
  • The calcaneus is first tarsal bone to ossify. It ossifies from one primary centre ( 3rd month of intrauterine life) and one secondary centre ( 6-8 years).
  • The talus is only tarsal bone that does not have muscle attachment.

Educational objective : The calcaneus, the largest tarsal bone, forms the heel, is cuboidal with six surfaces, and ossifies from one primary and one secondary center.

questions.text: All of the following muscles are attached to upper part of medial surface of tibia except
questions.solution:
The 3 muscles inserted into upper part of medial surface of tibia are as follow :

  • Sartorius: anterior compartment : Femoral Nerve
  • Gracilis: Medial compartment : Obturator nerve
  • Semitendinosus: Posterior compartment : Sciatic nerve

They represents the 3 compartment of thigh.

These three muscles are anchored below at one point and spread out above to span the pelvis, like three strings of a tent.

From this arrangement it appears that they act as Guy ropes to stabilize the bony pelvis on the femur.


Educational objective:

questions.text: A 50 years old female patient come to surgery department with complaint of swelling in her right groin for 2 years. On examination, surgeon found a single lobular lump below & lateral to left pubic tubercle. Which expanded on coughing. What is the diagnosis in above case?
questions.solution:
Femoral Hernia

The protrusion of abdominal contents through the femoral canal is called femoral hernia.

The femoral canal is an area of potential weakness in the abdominal wall through which abdominal contents may bulge out forming a femoral hernia.

The femoral hernia is more common in female because the femoral canal is wider in them than male. This is associated with wider pelvis and the smaller size of femoral vessels, in females.

The course of an enlarging hernial sac is typical. First it passes downwards through the femoral canal, than forwards through the saphenous opening and finally upwards along the superficial epigastric and superficial circumflex iliac vessels.

The covering of femoral hernia :

  • Skin
  • Superficial fascia
  • Cribriform fascia
  • Femoral sheath
  • Femoral septum

The lump of femoral hernia seen below and lateral to pubic tubercle.

The inguinal hernia lump seen above and medial to pubic tubercle and more common in male.

Educational objective: - The lump of femoral hernia seen below and lateral to pubic tubercle.

The inguinal hernia lump seen above and medial to pubic tubercle.

questions.text: A 60 years old male patient came to hospital with complaint of burning pain and numbness in the outer aspect of left thigh. The symptoms are progressively worsening over few months. There is no history of trauma or back pain. There is no weakness in lower limb. What is the most probable diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
The lateral cutaneous nerve of thigh is a branch of lumbar plexus. It emerges behind the inguinal ligament and divides into anterior and posterior branches. It supplies the skin on anterolateral side of thigh and on anterior part of gluteal region.

The entrapment of lateral cutaneous nerve of thigh below inguinal ligament is called Meralgia Paresthetica.

This leads to pain and numbness in lateral side of thigh.

Educational objective:

questions.text: What is the action of muscle attach to marked arrow in the image?
questions.solution:
The marked arrow in the image is anterior superior iliac spine (ASIS).

The muscle attach at ASIS is Sartorius.

Sartorius:

  • Origin: Anterior superior iliac spine
  • Insertion: Upper part of the medial surface of shaft of tibia.
  • Nerve supply: Femoral nerve
  • Action: Abductor and lateral rotator of thigh and flexion of leg at knee joint.

Sartorius muscle also plays a role in flexion of the hip. The actions of the Sartorius include:

  • Flexion of the thigh (hip)
  • Abduction of the thigh
  • Lateral rotation of the thigh
  • Flexion of the leg at the knee joint

However, in the question, the specific action being tested is abduction of the thigh. While Sartorius does assist in flexion of the hip, its primary action related to the thigh movement at the hip joint includes abduction and lateral rotation.

Educational objective:

questions.text: A 56 years old male patient visited to hospital with a noticeable limp. His pelvis drops on left side when he stands on right leg. There was no significant past medical history. On physical examination, he has weakness in hip abduction on right side. What is most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above patient has right gluteus medius and minimus muscle paralysis. So superior gluteal nerve is likely to injured in this case.

Normally when the body weight is supported on one limb, the glutei of the supported side raise the opposite and unsupported side of the pelvis.

However, if the abductor mechanism is defective, the unsupported side of the pelvis drops, and this is known as a positive Trendelenburg’s sign.

The sign is positive in defects of power, i.e. paralysis of the glutei medius and minimus; defects of the fulcrum, i.e. congenital or pathological dislocation of the hip; and defects of the weight, i.e. ununited fracture of the neck of femur.

Trendelenburg’s sign: a and b normal:

  • (a) When both feet are supporting the body weight, the pelvis (anterior superior iliac spine) on the two sides lies in the same horizontal plane.
  • (b) When only the right foot is supporting the body weight, the unsupported side of the pelvis is normally raised by the opposite gluteal medius and minimus.
  • (c) If the right glutei medius and minimus are paralysed, the unsupported left side of the pelvis drops. This is a positive Trendelenburg’s sign.
  • As per given case when patient stands on left foot, right side pelvis drops down. So left side gluteus medius and minimus are paralysed.
  • Remember - "Normal side (nerve) sinks down, i.e., left side droops with right side nerve injury."

Educational objectives : The patient likely has superior gluteal nerve injury, causing paralysis of the right gluteus medius and minimus, resulting in a positive Trendelenburg sign due to pelvis dropping on the unsupported side when weight is on one limb.

choices.text: Obturator Internus: Medial rotator of thigh

questions.text: Which of the following pair is incorrect for muscle and its action?
questions.solution: The actions of muscles of gluteal region are as follow:

choices.text: It is formed by ventral branches of ventral rami of L2, L3, L4
It enters the thigh by passing through obturator canal
Its anterior division supplies pectineus, adductor longus and Gracillis
Its anterior division supplies knee joint

questions.text: Which of the following statements is incorrect for obturator nerve?
questions.solution:
Obturator nerve:

  • It is chief nerve of medial compartment of the thigh.
  • It is formed by the ventral divisions of anterior primary rami of spinal nerve L2, L3, L4.
  • It enters the thigh by passing through the obturator canal.
  • Within obturator canal it divides into anterior and posterior divisions :

Anterior divisions:

  • Supplies pectineus, Adductor longus, Gracilis and adductor brevis
  • Gives a branch to the hip joint.
  • It ends by supplying the femoral artery

Posterior divisions:

  • Supplies Obturator externus, Adductor magnus, Adductor brevis (if not by anterior division)
  • It ends by supplying knee joint.

Educational objectives : The obturator nerve, arising from L2, L3, and L4, is the main nerve of the medial thigh compartment, dividing into anterior and posterior divisions that innervate various adductor muscles and joints.

choices.text: It arise from anterior surface of body of the pubis
It is inserted to linea aspera and adductor tubercle of femur
It is supplied by obturator nerve and tibial part of sciatic nerve
It cause adduction of thigh and extension of thigh

questions.text: Which of the following statement are incorrect for adductor magnus muscle
questions.solution:
Adductor magnus muscle :

Origin: Inferolateral part of ischial tuberosity, Ramus of ischium, Inferior ramus of pubis

Insertion: Medial margin of gluteal tuberosity, Linea aspera, Medial Supracondylar line, Adductor tubercle

Nerve supply:

  • Adductor part: Obturator nerve ( posterior division)
  • Hamstring part: Tibial part of sciatic nerve

Action:

  • Adductor part: adduction and medial rotation of thigh
  • Hamstring part: extension of the thigh

Educational objective :

The adductor magnus muscle originates from the ischial tuberosity and pubis, inserts along the linea aspera and adductor tubercle, and is innervated by the obturator and tibial nerves, functioning in thigh adduction, medial rotation, and extension.

questions.text: A 60 years old male patient, a chronic smoker presented to hospital with pain behind the left knee joint. He also complained of pain with exercise. On examination doctor found a pulsating lump behind the joint. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
As the patient has a pulsatile lump behind the knee, most probable diagnosis is Popliteal aneurysm.

  • The popliteal artery is more prone to aneurysm than any other artery in the body.
  • Clinically, popliteal aneurysm presents as a pulsatile midline swelling in the popliteal fossa.
  • Swelling on the back of knee can originate from the number of structure within and around the popliteal fossa.

choices.text: Descending genicular branch of femoral artery
Circumflex fibular from posterior tibial artery
Descending branch of medial circumflex femoral artery

questions.text: Which of the following artery does not form anastomosis around the knee joint?
questions.solution:
Anastomoses around knee joint are in form of complicated arterial network situated around the patella and around lower end of femur and upper end of tibia. It is formed :

Medially and above the condyle:

  • The descending genicular branch of femoral artery
  • Superior medial genicular artery

Medially and below the condyle:

  • Saphenous branch of descending genicular artery
  • Inferior medial genicular artery

Laterally and above the condyle:

  • Descending genicular branch of lateral circumflex femoral artery
  • Superior lateral genicular artery

Laterally and below the condyle:

  • Inferior lateral genicular artery
  • Anterior tibial recurrent artery
  • Posterior tibial recurrent artery
  • Circumflex fibular from posterior tibial artery

questions.text: A 40 years old male patient came to emergency department after accident with posterior dislocation of hip joint. On examination, doctor found that patient has lost of all movements below knee. He also has loss of sensation on back of thigh and whole leg except medial side of leg. Which of the following nerve is most likely to be injured?
questions.solution:
Sciatic Nerve:

It is the thickest nerve in the body.

It begins in the pelvis and terminates at the superior angle of popliteal fossa by dividing into tibial and common peroneal nerves.

Tibial nerve: supplies all the muscles of back of thigh and divides into medial and lateral plantar nerve.

Common peroneal nerve: divides into superficial peroneal nerve (supplies lateral compartment muscle) and deep peroneal nerve ( supplies anterior compartment muscle).

The sciatic nerve may be injured in posterior dislocation of hip joint. This results in loss of all movements below the knee with foot drop. There is sensory loss on back of the thigh and whole of the leg and the foot except the area innervated by saphenous nerve.

Femoral nerve: supplies the muscles of anterior compartment of thigh.

Obturator nerve: supplies the muscles of medial compartment of thigh

questions.text: A 23 years old male sprinter visited to hospital with pain in the back of his thigh after abruptly stopping during a race. He reports a sudden sharp pain and difficulty in walking. On examination, there is tenderness and swelling in posterior thigh. what is most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The muscles of back of thigh are called hamstring muscles, that is most likely undergo strain in the above patient.

Hamstring muscles : They are four in number :

  1. Semimembranosus
  2. Semitendinosus
  3. Long head of biceps femoris
  4. Ischial head of adductor magnus

The hamstring share the following characters :

  • Origin from the ischial tuberosity
  • Inserted into one of the bones of leg
  • Nerve supply from the tibial part of the sciatic nerve
  • They act as flexors of the knee and extensors of the hip.

The iliotibial band syndrome: The iliotibial band get irritated or swollen that leads to pain at the level of the lateral femoral epicondyle.

Quadriceps strain: Acute tearing injury of quadriceps muscles that leads to pain on anterior compartment of thigh.

Sciatica: Shooting pain along cutaneous distribution of the sciatic nerve and its terminal branches is known as sciatica.

questions.text: Which of the following pair is correct regarding sensory nerve supply of leg?
questions.solution:
The sensory nerve supply of leg is as follow :

  • Saphenous nerve: It is a branch of posterior division of femoral nerve. It Supplies the skin of most of medial area of the leg and medial border of the foot up to the ball of big toe.
  • Sural Nerve: It is a branch of tibial nerve. It supplies the skin of lower half of back of leg and lateral border of foot up to tip of the little toe.
  • Superficial peroneal nerve: It is a branch of common peroneal nerve. It supplies skin over lower one third of lateral side of leg and dorsum of foot.
  • Deep peroneal nerve: It is a branch of common peroneal nerve. It supplies the skin of cleft between the first and second toes.

questions.text: A 35 years old male patient came to hospital with compliant of difficulty in lifting the front part of foot. He also had decreased sensation over lateral part of leg and dorsum of foot. He had history of injury to his upper part of leg with table. Which nerve is most likely to injured in this case?
questions.solution:
The patient had injury at upper part of leg and foot drop so common peroneal nerve is most likely to damage in above case.

Common peroneal nerve is a terminal branch of sciatic nerve and divides into deep and superficial peroneal nerve at posterolateral side of neck of fibula. It is the most commonly injured nerve in the lower limb. This nerve is relatively unprotected.

  • Deep peroneal nerve supplies all muscles of anterior compartment and skin of 1st web space.
  • Superficial peroneal nerve supplies muscles of lateral compartment and skin of lower lateral part of leg and dorsum of foot.

Femoral nerve: is branch of lumbar plexus and supplies the muscles of front of thigh and skin of medial side of thigh, leg and medial border of foot.

Tibial nerve: is terminal branch of sciatic nerve and supplies muscles of back of leg and skin of back of leg and lower surface of heel.

Sciatic nerve: is branch of sacral plexus and Mostly damage in case of posterior dislocation of hip and penetrating wounds.

choices.text: 2 cm above the medial malleous
2 cm below and behind the medial malleous
2 cm below and behind the lateral malleous

questions.text: Where does the posterior tibial artery palpated?
questions.solution:
Posterior tibial artery is terminal branch of popliteal artery at lower border of the popliteus muscle.

It enters the back of leg by passing deep to the tendinous arch of the Soleus.

In the leg, it runs downwards and medially to reach to posteromedial side of ankle, midway between medial malleous and the medial tubercle of calcaneum.

It terminates deep to flexor retinaculum by dividing into lateral and medial plantar arteries.

The posterior tibial pulse can be felt against the calcaneum about 2 cm below and behind the medial malleous.

questions.text: A 65 years old diabetic female patient came to hospital with complaint of numbness and tingling in the sole of her foot. On examination, doctor observed decreased sensation on sole of her foot and week plantar flexion of the foot. Which of the following is most likely site of nerve compression or injury in this patient?
questions.solution:
The above patient has a compression of tibial nerve in tarsal tunnel.

The area between flexor retinaculum and calcaneum is called tarsal tunnel. Following structures are passing through tarsal tunnel are :

  • Tendon of the tibialis posterior
  • Tendon of flexor digitorum longus
  • Posterior tibial artery and its terminal branches
  • Tibial nerve and its terminal branches
  • Tendon of flexor hallucis longus

If the tibial nerve compressed below flexor retinaculum , it is called tarsal tunnel syndrome.

Paralysis of intrinsic muscles of sole and decreased sensation on sole of foot.

The common peroneal nerve is most likely compressed at neck of fibula.

The deep peroneal may be compressed in anterior compartment and superficial peroneal nerve may be compressed in lateral compartment.

Educational objective : The patient has tarsal tunnel syndrome from posterior tibial nerve compression in the tarsal tunnel, leading to intrinsic muscle paralysis and decreased sensation on the sole of the foot.

questions.text: A 50 years old traffic policemen visited to hospital with complaint of aching pain and heaviness in his legs after standing for long periods. His symptoms improve when he elevates leg. On examination doctor found prominent and tortuous veins on medial side of his legs. What is most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above patient has varicosities in great saphenous vein.

When the veins becomes dilated and tortuous they are called varicose veins.

If the valves in perforating veins or at the termination of superficial veins become incompetent , the defective veins become high pressure leaks through which the high pressure of the deep veins produced by the muscular contraction is transmitted to the superficial veins.

This results in dilatation of the superficial veins and to gradual degeneration of their wall producing varicose veins and varicose ulcers.

Arteriovenous malformation is a rare and complex vascular anomaly where there is an abnormal connection between the arteries and veins. That leads to redness and warmth in the skin.

Deep vein thrombosis: It is condition in which blood clot forms in a deep vein that leads to swelling and pain in the leg.

Elephantiasis: It is due to microfilaria parasites infection that leads to blockage of lymph vessels of lower limb causing hypertrophy of skin and subcutaneous tissue.

choices.text: Skin and fascia of Lower limb
Anterior abdominal wall below level of umbilicus

questions.text: Superficial inguinal lymph nodes drains the all of the following area except
questions.solution:
The inguinal lymph nodes are of two types :

Superficial inguinal lymph nodes : They are divided into three sets :

  • Lower vertical group : drain the skin and fascia of lower limb
  • Upper lateral group : drain of upper part of thigh, buttocks, flank and back below umbilicus
  • Upper medial group : drain anterior abdominal wall below umbilicus, perineum including external genitalia except glans, the anal canal below pectinate line, vagina below hymen and the penile part of male urethra.

Deep inguinal lymph nodes : They receives afferent from

  • The superficial inguinal nodes
  • The popliteal nodes
  • Glans penis or clitoris
  • Deep lymphatics of lower limb accompanying the femoral vessels

questions.text: A 50 years old traffic policeman presents to hospital with pain on the sole of foot near heel. The pain is worse with the first few steps in morning or after periods of rest. On examination doctor observed tenderness at the medial aspect of the heel. There is no history of trauma. What is the most likely diagnosis for patient?
questions.solution:
Plantar fasciitis

  • Inflammation of plantar aponeurosis.
  • Occurs in individuals who do a great deal of standing and walking.
  • It causes pain and tenderness in the sole of the foot, especially underneath the heel during standing.

Plantar aponeurosis:

  • Triangular in shape
  • Represent distal part of plantaris.
  • Apex attached to medial tubercle of calcaneum
  • Base divided into 5 processes which further split to superficial and deep slip
  • Superficial slip is attached to dermis of skin and deep slip embrace the flexor tendons
  • It fixes the skin of sole and protects the deeper structure.
  • It helps in maintaining the longitudinal arches of the foot.

Tarsal tunnel syndrome: It is due to a compression of tibial nerve between the flexor retinaculum and calcaneum. Symptoms includes tingling and numbness in sole of foot.

Achilles tendinitis: It is a inflammation of Achilles tendon due to increase physical activity mostly seen in athletes. Symptoms includes pain and tenderness around the ankle.

Stress fracture: Mostly affects the metatarsal due to sudden increase in sports activity.

questions.text: Identify the type of joint marked in the given image.
questions.solution:
The joint marked in the given image is inferior tibiofibular joint.

It is a syndesmosis uniting the lower ends of the tibia and the fibula.

The bony surfaces are connected by a very strong interosseous ligament, which forms the chief bond of union between the lower ends of these bones.

The joints can be classified based upon the type of connective tissue and presence of absence of a joint cavity into three types :

  1. Fibrous: the bones forming the joints are united by fibrous connective tissue. It is of 3 types :
    1. Sutures: bones are connected by sutural ligaments. e.g. sutures in skull.
    2. Syndesmosis: bones are connected by greater amount of connective tissues. e.g. interosseous radioulnar joint, interosseous tibiofibular joint, inferior tibiofibular joint etc.
    3. Gomphosis: specialized fibrous joint restricted to fixation of teeth in alveolar socket.
  2. Cartilaginous: Bones forming the joints are united by hyaline or fibrocartilage. It is of 2 types
    1. Primary: bones connected by hyaline cartilage. e.g. 1st chondrosternal joint etc
    2. Secondary: articular surface covered by hyaline cartilage that is connected by fibrocartilage. e.g. pubic symphysis, Intervertebral disc , Manubriosternal etc.
  3. Synovial: These joints posses a cavity and the articular ends of bones forming the joint are enclosed in fibrous capsule.

Types of synovial joints:

questions.text: Which of the following pair is incorrect for ligaments and its primitive origin?
questions.solution:
The Sacrotuberous ligament is a degenerated part of Long head of biceps femoris muscle.

It is a strong broad band of the fibrous tissue.

The upper end is attached from above downwards to Posterior Superior Iliac Spine , Posterior Inferior Iliac Spine and lateral border of sacrum and coccyx. Its lower end is attached to ischial tuberosity.

Sacrospinous ligament : is triangular ligament. Its apex is attached laterally to ischial spine and base is attached to outer edge of sacrum and coccyx. It is degenerated part of Coccygeus muscle.

Tibial collateral ligament : It is attached to medial epicondyle of femur superiorly and inferiorly divide into anterior and posterior part. The anterior part is attached to medial border of tibia and posterior part blends with medial meniscus and attached to medial condyle of tibia. Morphologically it represents degenerated tendon of adductor magnus muscle.

Fibular collateral ligament : It attached superiorly to lateral epicondyle of femur and inferiorly to head of fibula. Morphologically, it represents femoral attachment of peroneus longus.

questions.text: A 3 week old male infant bought to hospital by his parent, who are concerned about appearance of his foot. On examination, doctor observed that both feet are inverted, adducted and plantar flexed. What is the diagnosis in above case?
questions.solution:
The above case is club foot ( Talipes equinovarus)

Talipes equinovarus: It is commonest deformity of foot.

The foot is inverted, adducted and plantar flexed.

The condition may be associated with spina bifida.

  • Talipes calcaneovalgus : The foot is dorsiflexed and everted.
  • Talipes calcaneus : The patient walks on heel with forefoot raised.
  • Talipes varus : The patient walks on the outer border of foot which is inverted and adducted.
  • Talipes equinus : The patient walks on toes with the heel raised.
  • Talipes Valgus : The patient walks on inner border of foot which is everted and abducted.
  • Pes planus : Absence or collapse of the longitudinal arches of foot.
  • Pes cavus : Exaggeration of the longitudinal arches of the foot.

choices.text: It is made up of hyaline cartilage
Its ends are attached to tibia
It give rise to proprioceptive impulses

questions.text: Which of the statements is incorrect for marked arrow ligaments of knee joint?
questions.solution:
The marked arrow ligament of knee joint is Medial Meniscus.

The menisci are two fibrocartilaginous discs.

They deepen the articular surfaces of the Condyles  of the tibia and partially divide the joint cavity into upper and lower compartments.

They have two ends that are attached to the tibia.

The medial meniscus is nearly semicircular while lateral meniscus is nearly circular in shape.

Functions of menisci :

  • They help in making the articular surface more congruent.
  • The menisci serve as shock absorbers
  • They help in lubricating the joint cavity
  • Because of their nerve supply, they also have sensory function. They give rise to proprioceptive impulses.
